Problem:
Consider a system governed by the elliptic partial differential equation \\(\\nabla^2 u(x, y) = -\\lambda u(x, y)\\) in a region \\(D\\). We explore how the application of a Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\), which converts functions into their frequency components, influences our understanding of the solution \\(u(x, y)\\).

Can we determine the exact value of \\(\\lambda\\) in the original PDE solely from the Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}(u)\\) of the solution \\(u(x, y)\\)?
Explanation: Though the Fourier transform provides the frequency-domain representation of the solution, deducing the exact value of \\(\\lambda\\) from this alone is underdetermined because multiple values of \\(\\lambda\\) could potentially produce similar effects on the distribution of frequency components. Additional information about boundary conditions or specific forms of \\(u(x, y)\\) might be required.
